item.title: a different -kind of- writing process
item.description:
• Write 1st draft, it‚Äôs too long,
  • write second draft, it‚Äôs long,
  • write third draft, okay we‚Äôre getting somewhere, but maybe we need to start again,
  • write fourth draft, okay we‚Äôre heading in the right direction now.
  • Re-read fourth version, cut useless words, rephrase sections, cut a paragraph that isn‚Äôt needed, add a new one.

This is not my normal writing process. Normally I either write in one go and then edit or I write once, delete and then write again. This time I‚Äôm writing for someone else‚Äôs publication and there‚Äôs so much I could add. That‚Äôs what I realised on the second draft, I could say more. But the truth is, the reader wants something for them, they don‚Äôt care about the aspects I find interesting or the fine details. They want the interesting take away or idea for them.

That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm taking my time, and I‚Äôve not even finished yet

item.title: Turtles all the way down
item.description: One of the things I‚Äôve found really strange on the internet are the sort of ‚Äúpyramid‚Äù schemes. You know, the internet marketer, who teaches you internet marketing, so you too can become an internet marketer, in internet marketing. Or the writer, who writes books, on how to write books‚Ä¶about writing books. Or the YouTuber who makes YouTube videos about how you can make YouTube videos. Obviously not everyone who does internet marketing or teachers internet marketing only does internet marketing or only has experience in this field, but there are plenty of other ‚Äúfake it till you make it‚Äù folk, and it‚Äôs telling when they seem to produce people who do the exact same thing (just less successfully). I‚Äôll add, that It‚Äôs also why I find the sketchnote community concerning sometimes. Some people only seem to share sketchnotes of how to sketchnote‚Ä¶and that‚Äôs pretty weird.

item.title: Oh Hi there Micro.Blog
item.description:
So after this week Mac Power users podcast I finally got round to signing up for Micro.Blog. I had been meaning to do so for a bit, especially after seeing people like Zsolt Benke at decoding using the service on their own site. However I wondered if I should use it on my own site or whatever. In the end, I signed up for a Micro.blog blog as I wanted to help support the service as well. Paying $5 seems like a good way to do so and solved my overthinking.

So why did I sign up in the first place.

My increasing announance at Social Media (twitter)

I‚Äôve increasingly felt that social media is very ‚Äúmeh‚Äù. I hate what Facebook has become as it increasingly tried to grab my attention with cheap tricks and tracks everything I do (no matter if I try to stop that). Twitter too isn‚Äôt perfect with its lack of efforts to stop trolling and abuse.

My announance at blogging

Likewise I‚Äôm fed up of the ‚Äúprofessional blogging culture‚Äù. There are so many ‚Äúhave tos‚Äù with blogging now like:
- write long posts - have links - be helpful - only show the good sides - no link posts - be on a single focus topic And so on and so on. All great advice if you want to make money, but as CJ Chilvers says

‚Äúone is a business model, one is a life model‚Äù

That‚Äôs what I‚Äôm hoping for in this site. Somewhere to play, somewhere to create and somewhere to be unprofessional.
